Current period is 2000–2030 and future period is 2040–2070.Full size imageIn ESEA, high moist heat is possible when Bowen ratio is high and soil moisture is low (Fig. 4a and S4; high and low values, in terms of intensity rather than frequency, of different variables, are quantified locally, for example, high Bowen ratio >0.6, low soil moisture <900 kg/m2, and high moist heat >26 °C). When the soil moisture is high, it will also mediate near-surface air temperature and moist heat, forming a negative correlation between soil moisture and moist heat. By contrast, a less strong but still negative correlation between soil moisture and moist heat is found over EUS (Fig. 3a, b). Nevertheless, in EUS, one aspect different from other domains is that moist heat is in general low when the Bowen ratio and soil moisture are both low (Fig. 4e and S6), which deduces the fact that we can’t overlook dry environments where both near-surface air temperature and relative humidity are low.In ARP, the situations where high Bowen ratio, low soil moisture, and high moist heat concurrently happen are not evidently dominating, while high moist heat can still happen with high soil moisture (Fig. 4c and S5). Despite soil desiccation accompanied with high Bowen ratio still tends to induce high moist heat, limited soil moisture-temperature interactions lead to minimal mediation of near-surface air temperatures (Fig. S13)17. Accordingly, especially when Bowen ratio is low and soil moisture is not severely limited, moist heat is more influenced by relative humidity compared with other domains. In the meantime, as higher relative humidity increases moist heat (Fig. S1), higher relative humidity is accompanied by relatively higher soil moisture and in this way facilitates a moderate but positive correlation between soil moisture and moist heat, especially in some regions of ARP and MNAF (Figs. 3,4, S5, and S10).Comparative analysis between current and future periods clearly indicates a worsening of the moist heat conditions across all studied domains (Fig. 4 and S4–S12). In the future period, the most common levels of moist heat exceed the thresholds typically associated with normal wet-hot days (for example, in ESEA, 27.1 °C > 27 °C, Fig. 4b; in ARP, 28 °C > 27 °C, Fig. 4d) in most domains. The only two potential exceptions appear to be EUS and CAM (Fig. 4, S6, and S8), where the most common levels of moist heat are below 27 °C, but the escalation of moist heat still makes substantial wet-hot days. These findings point to an alarming future where the baseline for moist heat is dramatically higher, presenting severe implications for regional climate dynamics, human health, and agriculture. One thing to note here is that sometimes the common moist heat (Fig. 3b, d, f) does not indicate expected results of soil moisture-moist heat interactions. For example, in ESEA, common moist heat in uncoupled experiments is higher than that in coupled experiments (Fig. 4b), suggesting soil desiccation doesn’t necessarily induce a higher moist heat in ESEA in both periods. However, general distributions in coupled experiments are found with more occurrences of severe moist heat compared with those in uncoupled ones (Fig. 4b).Increasing Population Exposure to Moist HeatPopulation exposure to humid heatwaves is another focus of our study. A substantial increase in the population exposed to more than 6 days for average normal humid heatwave during the maxima season is found across numerous regions in the selected domains (Fig. 5a), driven by growing population in some regions and rising global moist heat. However, an exception to this trend is observed in AU and some parts in CAM and ESA (Fig. 5a), where the data suggest no increases or less increases in the number of people exposed to these hazardous conditions in the future compared to the current period. Despite these localized situations, most domains experience significant increases in population exposed to average humid heatwave reaching a dangerous moist heat level (>27 °C).Fig. 5: Projected changes of population exposure to moist heat.a Changes of population count which will be exposed to seasonally mean normal humid heatwave duration above 6 days across the current period (2000, 2010, 2020, and 2030) and future period (2040, 2050, 2060, and 2070). The extensions in color bars indicate values beyond the limits, otherwise, the values are within the limits. b–g, and h, Changes of population percentage exposed to seasonally mean humid heatwave duration above 6 days and related soil moisture contributions. The regional values shown here are area-weighted. The oceans are excluded for these domains. HH indicates humid heatwaves.Full size imageAcross all analyzed domains, climate model data reveal a clear and consistent trend of increasing population exposure to average humid heatwave longer than 6 days (Fig. 5). Each subplot in Fig. 5 demonstrates a marked upward trajectory in the percentage of the population affected by these moist heat conditions. ESEA, ARP, and MNAF are identified as the domains facing the most severe moist heat conditions. In these domains, during current period (2000–2030), population exposure to average normal humid heatwaves is in general already more than 20%, in ESEA and ARP, the current situation is more severe as the population exposure to average normal humid heatwaves can be more than 40% (Fig. 5c, d). In the future period of these domains, population exposure to average normal humid heatwave longer than 6 days could reach as high as 80% by 2060, with some domains, such as ARP, potentially having 80% of their population exposure to humid heatwaves since 2030 (Fig. 5c). In the meantime, in ESEA, the situation is serious but expected to happen later, with population exposure to average extreme humid heatwave longer than 6 days reaching 50% by 2070 (Fig. 5d). The high levels of exposure projected for these domains underscore the critical need for immediate and sustained efforts to enhance moist heat mitigation, particularly for vulnerable regions most at risk from the health impacts of extreme heat.While people in EUS and ESA are projected to experience comparatively less severe moist heat conditions than domains like ESEA, ARP, and MNAF, the outlook remains concerning. By 2070, it is anticipated that population exposure to average normal humid heatwave longer than 6 days will be over 50% in both EUS and ESA (Fig. 5b, f), which still represents a substantial public health challenge. In CAM and AU domains, the projected increases in population exposure to moist heat are less pronounced compared to other domains. However, in CAM, for example, more than 20% of the population is projected to be exposed to average normal humid heatwave longer than 6 days since 2060 (Fig. 5e), which highlights the importance of maintaining awareness and preparedness in CAM and AU. In those places, the impacts of moist heat, though less severe in scale, could still pose significant risks to public health and human well-being.Soil moisture changes predominantly amplify population exposure to average humid heatwave longer than 6 days in all the domains with notable exceptions in the ARP and MNAF (Fig. 5c, g). The temporal dynamics of soil moisture contributions to population exposure to moist heat vary regionally: ESEA experiences stronger effects during the present period and does not show an increasing trend with soil moisture impacts (Fig. 5d), while intensifications of soil moisture contributions are projected in EUS, CAM, and ESA (Fig. 5b, e, f). In EUS, ESEA, and ESA, soil moisture changes amplify population exposure to moist heat more significantly compared with other domains (Fig. 5b, d, f), for example, more than 10% of the local population of ESEA exposed to average extreme humid heatwave longer than 6 days are caused by soil moisture changes in 2000 (Fig. 5d). In contrast, AU shows minimal soil moisture-driven population exposure to moist heat events, with less than 3% of its population affected by soil moisture changes in general (Fig. 5h).DiscussionThe increasing intensity of moist heat is found across various domains (Figs. 2, 4, S2, and S4-S12). All selected domains show an increasing trend in moist heat and wet-hot days, particularly in mid-latitude areas (Fig. 2 and S2). The observed increases in these domains suggest a broader geographic expansion of extreme moist heat conditions, which highlights the emerging vulnerability of mid-latitude regions to moist heat extremes. To understand moist heat trend, soil moisture is critical in its role of influencing regional climate responses. Across many domains, soil moisture changes, including long-term trend of soil moisture and its short-term variability, contribute more to the regional changes of moist heat than the global average (Fig. S2).The relationship between soil moisture and moist heat is not uniform across domains. In current period (2000–2030), the effects of both soil moisture variability and trend are most significant across the MNAF, ESEA, AU, and ESA (Fig. 3c). Differences of soil moisture between pdLC and CTL lead to more responses in moist heat in the future period (2040–2070) across those domains (Fig. 3d, e). Predominantly (semi-)arid regions such as ARP and MNAF indicate that soil moisture increases could potentially mitigate the intensity of moist heat and reduce the frequency of wet-hot days (Fig. 4d, S2, S3, S5b and S10b). Nevertheless, with increasing soil moisture trends (Fig. S3)28,29, mediating effects of soil moisture have a limit and do not change much (soil moisture effects even become less mitigating in some regions; Fig. 3c–e and S2) as expected (more soil moisture increases are accompanied with more moist heat mitigation if the correlation between soil moisture and moist heat is negative), which conforms the fact that positive correlations are found over some regions in ARP and MNAF (Fig. 3a, b). These findings are consistent with some former research results, in which elevated surface humidity are caused by relatively higher soil moisture and increased latent heat flux2,19. Moreover, the advection of humid air masses from neighboring water bodies, such as the Mediterranean Sea or the Red Sea, when combined with high solar radiation and specific boundary layer conditions, may provide the necessary moisture that leads to the observed moderate but positive soil moisture-moist heat correlation in some places2.Sometimes increases in moist heat are not necessarily driven by additional local surface drying with a higher Bowen ratio (Fig. 4a, c, S4, S5, and S7–S10), suggesting that factors other than dry soil can lead to significant thermal stress without further increases in the Bowen ratio. Instead, large-scale atmospheric dynamics often become the dominant factor in leading to significant moist heat stress. By remaining in place for days or even weeks, a blocking high creates a heat dome effect. This pattern leads to prolonged clear skies, allowing for maximum solar radiation, and causes subsidence, where air from higher places in the atmosphere sinks. Lower surface albedo compared with desert in coastal areas also facilitates heating. As the air sinks, it is compressed and warmed adiabatically, significantly increasing surface temperatures over a vast area independent of local soil moisture changes30. The horizontal transport of air, or advection, is another critical factor. Hot, dry air masses originating from desert regions or continental interiors can be transported over long distances. This influx of a pre-heated air mass can rapidly and dramatically increase local temperatures. In such cases, the extreme heat is imported rather than generated by local land-atmosphere energy exchanges, meaning severe moist heat can occur without further changes in the local Bowen ratio31.Similar effects are also particularly pronounced in low-elevation, coastal regions (Fig. S14) of ESEA, AU, CAM, and ESA, where clear skies yield strong solar radiation and contribute to severe moist heat conditions2. Therefore, high moist heat is possible when both Bowen ratio and soil moisture are low (Fig. 4, S4, and S7–S9). However, ESEA, AU, CAM, and ESA exhibit a broader range of soil moisture levels. On the one hand, continuing soil desiccation tends to amplify moist heat in the future (Fig. 4a, e, S2, S4b, and S7b-S9b), from which it is deduced that maintaining soil moisture close to climatological values could further reduce extreme heat (Fig. S3; see Detection of Soil Moisture Impacts on Moist Heat in Methods for detailed explanations of the experimental setting). On the other hand, even though higher soil moisture increases evaporation, thereby enhancing relative humidity, it will also mediate near-surface air temperature and in this way moist heat with soil moisture-temperature interactions, which are more evident in ESA and CAM (Figs. S7 and S8). Therefore, moist heat is inhibited with more soil moisture, which facilitate a negative correlation between soil moisture and moist heat, especially in ESA and CAM (Fig. 3, S7, and S8). In conclusion, the complex interplay between soil moisture, near-surface air temperature, and relative humidity underpins the distribution of moist heat across different domains. This interplay underscores the critical role of soil moisture in modulating heat stress and highlights the urgent need for region-specific mitigation strategies to address the escalating impacts of climate change. These findings emphasize the need for more nuanced climate models that can accurately simulate the non-linear and localized interactions between soil moisture and atmospheric conditions.People in most domains are found to be facing more frequent and severe moist heat events (Fig. 5 and S15). The impending threat needs to be recognized in local ability to cope with humid heatwaves and expedite the implementation of mitigating facilities, such as air conditioning systems and urban green spaces, which are crucial for reducing moist heat stress32,33. Interestingly, domains like AU and CAM are expected to see relatively smaller increases in population exposure to moist heat. This is partly due to the fact that, in many areas of both domains, average humid heatwave during maxima seasons will not reach 6 days. However, it is important to note that even in these domains, albeit less than 6 days of all the humid heatwave occurrences during maxima seasons, severe moist heat events remain possible, warranting timely and comprehensive strategies at both governmental and individual levels. In addition, in AU, the projected increases in moist heat are concentrated primarily in inland areas, which are less densely populated compared to coastal regions. Impacts of soil moisture on population exposure to humid heatwaves exhibit complex spatial patterns. Although in most areas, soil moisture changes tend to contribute to more population exposed to humid heatwaves. In MNAF and ARP, soil moisture changes sometimes mitigate population exposure by dampening moist heat (Fig. 3c, d and Fig. 5c, g), though this effect is partly offset in southern Europe due to relatively positive soil moisture-moist heat feedbacks (Fig. 3c, d). In EUS, the continued great contributions from soil moisture post-2000 can be attributed to higher impacts from soil moisture in the middle part (Fig. 3). Additionally, contributions from soil moisture on population exposure to moist heat (Fig. 5) are related to soil moisture’s variations relative to its climatological values (Fig. S3). In domains where soil desiccation strongly amplifies moist heat such as CAM and ESA, soil moisture is projected to decrease and in this way facilitates more population exposure in the future (Fig. 5 and S3).We conclude that our results provided by CMIP6 datasets are a qualitatively robust representation of the large-scale global patterns of the evaluated variables. Bias of moist heat between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land results are moderate, with most regions having a bias lower than 4.5 °C (Fig. 1e). However, in MNAF and ARP, correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are generally lower in CMIP6 compared with ERA5-Land (Fig. 1f), which indicates those positive correlations should be greater but not reflected in our CMIP6 results. Similarly, underestimations of correlations between soil moisture and moist heat exist in other domains. As most regions have negative correlations, the positive bias between CMIP6 and ERA5-Land indicates that the correlations between soil moisture and moist heat ought to be more negative and thus relatively stronger.A critical source of discrepancy lies in the parameterization of soil hydrology. For instance, climate models do not have the same setting of soil profile, they might differ, and in this way have different representation of the soil moisture34,35,36,37. In high-altitude regions, climate models show deficiencies in simulating cold-region hydrological processes, such as the thawing of snowpack and frozen ground. These processes can introduce large volumes of water into the soil column, and misrepresentations of those can lead to significant biases in soil moisture, energy fluxes, and thus moist heat dynamics during the summer season38,39.The choice of maxima season for studying moist heat stress is crucial for accurately assessing the potential impacts on human health and infrastructure. To our knowledge, our study is pioneering in its adoption of different maxima seasons for different regions, which allows us to focus on the periods when moist heat stress is most likely to endanger human health. Moreover, the top 10% of extreme conditions is focused on when evaluating moist heat. This approach ensures that our analysis captures the highest potential impacts, as extreme moist heat events near their upper thresholds are most critical for public health.Effective land management is critical for mitigating humid heatwave impacts on human populations. Irrigation is often highlighted for its ability to modify local soil moisture and reduce temperature extremes, potentially decreasing heatwave exposure for 0.79 to 1.29 billion people40. However, the benefits of irrigation are not universal. In regions where soil moisture and moist heat are positively correlated, particularly where relative humidity exerts more influence, irrigation may inadvertently increase heat stress by raising air humidity (Fig. 3 and S14)41,42. Additionally, water scarcity in arid regions further limits the feasibility of widespread irrigation43,44. While irrigation may be effective in some areas, its use must be carefully calibrated to avoid exacerbating moist heat stress in certain regions.Our analysis is intentionally constrained to the role of soil moisture as a foundational, large-scale driver to moist heat extremes through comparing two experiments with different soil moisture setting (see Detection of Soil Moisture Impacts on Moist Heat in Methods). We acknowledge, however, that a complete picture of moist heat modulation requires considering additional anthropogenic or natural forcings. For example, future investigations should integrate the impacts of urbanization, which is a significant driver of observed surface warming at local and regional scales, altering thermal and humidity regimes45. Moreover, a meta-analysis of numerous studies confirms that urban green spaces provide measurable cooling benefits, though their magnitude can vary significantly with park size and vegetation type46. Anthropogenic aerosols are also important factors which influence regional temperature and humidity, through modifying the solar radiation, cloud properties, and precipitation47. A systematic assessment of how these distinct yet interacting drivers collectively modulate the soil moisture-driven moist heat signal is a crucial further step for a holistic risk assessment.In addition, future work will aim to disentangle soil moisture impacts on moist heat by distinguishing between short-term transient fluctuations and long-term drying trends. High-resolution data could complement this analysis by revealing how the variability of soil moisture across different time scales either amplifies or dampens humid heatwaves. However, the broad geographical domains used in this study occasionally mask significant intra-regional heterogeneity in soil moisture’s impact on moist heat. Incorporating higher spatial resolution in climate models would therefore allow future studies to better capture the nuanced interactions between soil moisture and moist heat, particularly in urban environments. Fine-scale spatial differences are critical in evaluating urban settings where microclimates can vary dramatically over short distances due to factors like building density, green space distribution, and water bodies48,49. Higher resolution will enable researchers to better understand how moist heat stress interacts with urban infrastructure and population density and thus identify localized vulnerabilities to moist heat. Moreover, refining the spatial resolution of climate models will facilitate more accurate predictions of moist heat-related impacts on public health and the effectiveness of mitigation strategies such as urban greening and land management practices.MethodsCMIP6 DataIn this study, we utilized daily near-surface air temperature, near-surface relative humidity, surface sensible heat flux, surface latent heat flux, and total soil moisture in the historical experiment, the Shared Socioeconomic Pathway (SSP) 585 experiment in Scenario Model Intercomparison Project (ScenarioMIP)50,51, and LFMIP-pdLC experiment of LS3MIP27 from three climate models within CMIP626 (Tab. S1). CMIP6 dataset used in this research has demonstrated robust performance in capturing global soil moisture dynamics and land-atmosphere coupling strength8,27,52,53. LS3MIP is a coordinated experimental framework intended to elucidate the complex interplay between terrestrial surface processes, especially soil moisture, and climate dynamics. This project is set to reveal the critical role of those land surface-climate interactions in affecting atmospheric conditions and modulating extreme events including heatwaves and droughts27. Scenario MIP and historical experiment from CMIP6 is widely used in numerous former studies8,54. The analysis of historical and ScenarioMIP data, referred to hereafter as CTL, minus the LFMIP-pdLC results allows us to isolate the effects of soil moisture changes on moist heat by accounting for both (a) the removal of multidecadal and interannual soil moisture trends and (b) the exclusion of short-term soil moisture variations on sub-seasonal timescale. For consistency, all climate model datasets were interpolated onto a common grid of 2.5° longitude by 1.875° latitude using a conservative remapping technique55. This interpolation enabled the use of a multi-model ensemble mean in our analysis. Only three climate models are chosen because of the availability of daily variable data in both CTL and LFMIP-pdLC experiments.Detection of Soil Moisture Impacts on Moist HeatEach of three climate models from the CMIP6 dataset (please refer to CMIP6 data of Methods for further details on the models) has a fully-coupled control run (CTL) and two experiments (pdLC and rmLC) where soil moisture is prescribed. In this paper, we focus on the pdLC experiment alongside the CTL to quantify the effects of soil moisture changes, represented as CTL–pdLC. CTL experiment features fully coupled and interactive soil moisture. In the corresponding pdLC experiment, by prescribing a repeating seasonal climatology of soil moisture derived from the 1980–2014 control simulation, soil moisture influences can be isolated (detailed information on the CMIP6 experiments can be found in CMIP6 data of Methods)27. Crucially, both simulations are forced with identical sea surface temperature and sea ice conditions, ensuring that any divergence in their outputs can be attributed solely to the soil moisture variability27. To investigate the contribution of soil moisture changes to moist heat and population exposure to it, we examine the comparative moist heat estimates between CTL and pdLC. Soil moisture impacts on moist heat (°C) and population exposure (%) are quantified in this research accordingly.Statistical significance in moist heat comparisons between the present period (2000–2030) and the future period (2040–2070), as well as between CTL and pdLC, is determined using the Anderson-Darling test (AD test)56. The decision to compare the period of 2000–2030 with the nearer future period of 2040–2070, rather than a historical period with a more distant future such as 2070–2100, ensures a more relevant investigation of changes in moist heat levels and population exposure to moist heat events. The correlations between soil moisture and moist heat are quantified using the Spearman correlation coefficient57, with statistical significance assessed via the Spearman rho test58. These correlations are calculated using the bias between CTL and pdLC runs. The seasonality and climatological trend of soil moisture and moist heat, that is, co-varying signals of the two variables in both experiments, will be removed, facilitating identifications of possible non-linear relationships between soil moisture and moist heat.ERA5-Land DatasetThis study utilized the ERA5-Land global reanalysis dataset to validate the results from CMIP6 dataset. ERA5-Land is a product of the European Centre for Medium-Range Weather Forecasts (ECMWF) and provides a consistent, high-resolution view of land surface variables from 1950 to the near present59. It was generated by replaying the land component of the ERA5 climate reanalysis, driven by atmospheric forcing from the ERA5 atmospheric reanalysis. For consistency, ERA5-Land datasets were interpolated onto a common grid of 2.5° longitude by 1.875° latitude using a conservative remapping technique55.Near-surface air temperature (T), near-surface dewpoint temperature (Td), near-surface volumetric soil water (SM, %) from the depth 0–7 cm (SM1), 7–28 cm (SM2), 28–100 cm (SM3), and 100–289 cm (SM4) are used from ERA5-Land, but near-surface relative humidity is not directly available. In order to derive relative humidity, firstly saturation vapor pressure is calculated as60:$${SVP}(T)=6.1094\times {e}^{\frac{17.625\times T}{243.04+T}}$$
                    (1)
                Near-surface relative humidity is then defined as the ratio of the actual vapor pressure to the saturation vapor pressure at the current near-surface air temperature:$${RH}=\frac{{e}^{\frac{17.625\times {T}_{d}}{243.04+{T}_{d}}}\,}{{e}^{\frac{17.625\times T}{243.04+T}}\,}\times 100$$
                    (2)
                CTL and pdLC differ in total soil moisture (water summed over all soil layers), which is not available in ERA5-Land datasets. Therefore, from ERA5-Land datasets, we summed all layers’ volumetric soil water content (%) multiplied by its respective layer depth and water density to generate the total soil moisture (kg/m2).Definition of DomainsTo enhance the characterization of regional soil moisture effects, we utilize the updated climate reference regions from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change’s Sixth Assessment Report (IPCC AR6). These regions are delineated based on consistent regional climate characteristics derived from both observational data and climate modelling (CMIP6) datasets61. Seven domains are set for this study: East, South, and Southeast Asia (ESEA), Australia (AU), Eastern United States (EUS), Central America (CAM), Arabian Peninsula (ARP), Mediterranean region and Northern Africa (MNAF), and Eastern South America (ESA) (Figs. 1, 2, 5, and S3).Identification and Classification of Moist HeatMany different methods and indices exist to quantify moist heat22,62,63. Here, we use a discomfort index (DI) to classify moist heat64 (21–24 °C, <50% of population in discomfort; 24–27 °C, >50% of population in discomfort; 27–29 °C, most of the population in discomfort; 29–32 °C, everyone feels severe stress; >32 °C, state of emergency)22,65. DI serves as a robust metric for quantifying perceived thermal stress, derived from empirical studies by the U.S. Weather Bureau. Critically, DI demonstrates strong correlation with physiological responses, particularly sweat rates during both rest and exercise, underscoring its relevance in assessing human thermal comfort and potential heat-related health risks66. Modified discomfort index (MDI) is not adopted as it doesn’t correspond to the widely used categories of discomfort we used in this research22,65,67. In addition, DI demonstrates remarkable concordance with the wet-bulb globe temperature (WBGT), a widely-used metric to measure moist heat22,62,63, exhibiting exceptionally high coefficients of determination66. However, necessary variables such as black globe temperature (Tg) and water vapor pressure to calculate WBGT are not available in the climate model dataset we used. As a result, DI is a more efficient metric ready to be used.To derive DI, wet-bulb temperature (WBT) needs to be calculated first. Historically, WBT calculations were computationally intensive, prompting the use of approximations of WBT68.$$\begin{array}{lll}WBT=T* \arctan \left(0.151977* \left({\left(\mathrm{rh}+8.313659\right)}^{1/2}\right)\right)\\\qquad\quad\;\;\,+\arctan \left(T+\mathrm{rh}\right)-\arctan \left(\mathrm{rh}-1.676331\right)\\\qquad\quad\;\;\,+\,0.00391838* \left({\mathrm{rh}}^{3/2}\right)* \arctan \left(0.023101* \mathrm{rh}\right)-4.686035\end{array}$$
                    (3)
                Discomfort index can then be expressed as:$${DI}=0.5* {WBT}+0.5* T$$
                    (4)
                where T is the near-surface 2 m air temperature, rh is the near-surface 2 m relative humidity as we focus on the impacts of moist heat on humans’ living condition. WBT is the wet-bulb temperature68. Days with moist heat above or equal with 27 °C and 29 °C are defined as normal wet-hot days and extreme wet-hot days according to the DI levels (Fig. 2a, b), respectively.Apart from tropical regions, moist heat extremes occur mainly from June to August in the Northern Hemisphere and from December to February in the Southern Hemisphere (Fig. S16). Tropical regions, influenced by consistent solar insolation and monsoonal patterns, generally have stable temperature and humidity69. However, monsoons can shift the timing of moist heat, with extreme moist heat preceding or following monsoons70,71. Therefore, we identified the month by ranking monthly mean moist heat values in each grid, focusing on the hottest month and its two adjacent months in our research. The relevant month and season are defined as maxima month and season. As no significant shifts are found in maxima month for moist-heat extremes across future scenarios (Fig. S16)4, we utilized consistent maxima seasons in current and future periods respectively.Our study uniquely adopts different maxima seasons across regions, focusing on the period of most severe moist heat stress. In addition, to quantify moist heat levels, we analyzed the top 10% of occurrences, which is crucial for understanding potential human impacts. When examining the relationship between soil moisture, Bowen ratio, and moist heat, we focused on occurrences where the Bowen ratio exceeds 0 and lies within the lower 90%. This approach minimizes the influences of outliers that skew the Bowen ratio distribution (Fig. S17).Population Dataset and ExposureGiven that population exposure to moist heat is influenced by both demographic factors and moist heat characteristics, our research integrates future population trends to reduce uncertainties in estimating changes in population exposure. To this end, we utilize gridded global population data for the years 2000, 2010, 2020, 2030, 2040, 2050, 2060, and 2070 to assess exposure to moist heat. The dataset, based on the data of 2000, aligns both quantitatively and qualitatively with the SSPs (specifically SSP585 in this study)72,73. The dataset’s spatial resolution is 1/8° by 1/8° in both longitude and latitude. To harmonize the spatial resolution and grid availability between climate and population projections, we aggregate the population data into 2.5° × 1.875° grids by summing the total population within the 1/8° × 1/8° grids that fall within each grid of climate data55. This interpolation facilitates the quantification of population exposure to moist heat, calculated as follows:$${{PE}}_{{percent}}={P}_{a}/{P}_{{all}}$$
                    (5)
                $${{PE}}_{a{bsolute}}={P}_{a}$$
                    (6)
                In a certain region, PEabsolute indicates the population count exposed to moist heat extremes. To better quantify the exposure of populations to increasing moist heat, we also adopted a percentage-based approach with respect to changing local population. In this way, the influences from the demographic shifts can be eliminated, which allows for a robust assessment of population exposure to moist heat. PEpercent indicates the exposed population percentage relative to the total population. Pa indicates the population count which is exposed to average humid heatwaves longer than a certain duration, Pall is the count of the total population.To investigate cumulative heat stress and human acclimatization, apart from solely moist heat stress measurements, we defined normal humid heatwaves as at least 3 consecutive days above 27 °C (normal wet-hot days) and extreme humid heatwaves for 29 °C (extreme wet-hot days). Seasonally humid heatwave duration is calculated as the mean value of each humid heatwave across the whole maxima season of a year. The population exposure to seasonally humid heatwave duration above 6 days and soil moisture impacts on it are quantified in this study.

Data availability
              
              Gridded data of global population count are available from SEDAC of NASA73. The CMIP6 model simulations are from Earth System Grid Federation (https://aims2.llnl.gov/search). ERA5-Land data are from Copernicus Climate Change Service (https://cds.climate.copernicus.eu/datasets/derived-era5-land-daily-statistics?tab=download)59.

items.title: Leaders at COP30 should promote solar and wind power over mega-dams
Nations at COP30 must cancel fossil-fuel concessions to keep the Paris agreement in reach
“No a nuovi condoni edilizi. Sì al diritto alla casa”. L’appello e le proposte di Legambiente
items.description: Aumenta in Italia la pressione del cemento illegale: 48.335 reati accertati dal 2021 al 2024, con una crescita dell’43,5%. L’Istat segnala l’aumento
items.body:
17 Novembre 2025

Legambiente

17 Novembre 2025

Comunicati stampa

cemento

“No a nuovi condoni edilizi. Sì al diritto alla casa”. L’appello e le proposte di Legambiente

17 Novembre 2025

Legambiente

17 Novembre 2025

Comunicati stampa

cemento

Aumenta in Italia la pressione del cemento illegale: 48.335 reati accertati dal 2021 al 2024, con una crescita dell’43,5%. L’Istat segnala l’aumento delle costruzioni abusive nel 2022 del 9,1%. In Campania ogni 100 case legali se ne costruiscono 50,4 illecite, che diventano 54,1 in Calabria. Eseguito solo il 15,3% delle oltre 70mila ordinanze di demolizione emesse da 435 Comuni delle regioni più a rischio (Campania, Puglia, Calabria, Sicilia e Lazio). 
“I dati parlano chiaro: l’Italia ha bisogno di un Piano nazionale di lotta all’abusivismo edilizio, non di un ulteriore, sciagurato, condono. Al bisogno di casa si risponda con la rigenerazione urbana senza consumo di suolo e risorse adeguate all’edilizia pubblica”. Le proposte di Legambiente. 
Nel nostro Paese, dopo il blocco causato dal Covid, è ripartito, insieme al mercato dell’edilizia, l’abusivismo edilizio. Lo dimostrano i numeri raccolti da Legambiente nel Rapporto Ecomafia nel triennio 2022-2024, relativi al ciclo illegale del cemento, che riguarda soprattutto i reati in materia di edilizia e urbanistica. Ma è anche al centro di un allarme, inascoltato, lanciato dall’Istat nel rapporto sul Bes (Benessere equo e sostenibile) del 2022: “Si stima, in particolare, un incremento netto delle abitazioni abusive – afferma l’Istat – in una misura che non si osservava dal 2004 (+9,1%), segnale di un possibile aggancio della componente illegale alla ripresa post-pandemica dell’edilizia residenziale”. Non basta: “Più che le variazioni congiunturali, tuttavia, a preoccupare è la lunga persistenza del fenomeno, in forza del quale, in gran parte del Paese, una quota significativa della produzione edilizia continua a operare fuori dalla legalità, nell’aspettativa di futuri condoni. Nel frattempo, il mancato rispetto di piani urbanistici, vincoli di tutela e norme di sicurezza scarica costi altissimi sulla società in termini di degrado del paesaggio, rischio sismico e dissesto idrogeologico”.
I DATI 
L’incremento registrato dall’Istat trova una puntuale conferma nei dati frutto dell’attività svolta dalle forze dell’ordine e dalle Capitanerie di porto: dal 2021 al 2022 i reati nel ciclo del cemento crescono del 28,8%. Un’escalation che prosegue anno dopo anno, fino a toccare i 13.621 illeciti penali accertati nel 2024, con un incremento del 43,5% rispetto al 2021.
Invece di rafforzare l’attività di demolizione del nuovo abusivismo edilizio, è accaduto esattamente il contrario. Nel 2021 è stata di fatto svuotata con una circolare del ministero dell’Interno la norma, introdotta su proposta di Legambiente nel 2020, che stabilisce il potere sostitutivo dei Prefetti quando i Comuni non eseguono le ordinanze di demolizione, limitandone l’efficacia solo a quelle emesse dopo l’entrata in vigore della norma. Negli anni successivi non sono stati rifinanziati i fondi disponibili sia presso il Ministero delle Infrastrutture che presso la Cassa depositi e prestiti per sostenere i Comuni da punto di vista economico nelle attività di demolizione, entrambi al momento privi di risorse. Gli effetti sono evidenti: a dicembre 2022 risultava eseguito solo il 15,3% delle oltre 70mila ordinanze di demolizione emesse dai 435 Comuni delle cinque regioni a maggiore rischio di mattone illegale (Campania, Puglia, Calabria, Sicilia e Lazio) che hanno risposto al monitoraggio civico promosso da Legambiente con la campagna “Abbatti l’abuso”.
IL COMMENTO 
“Ancora una volta, guarda caso alla vigilia di un appuntamento elettorale, in questo caso le elezioni regionali in Campania – afferma Stefano Ciafani, presidente nazionale di Legambiente – siamo costretti a contrastare l’ennesima proposta di riapertura dei termini del condono edilizio. Ogni volta le motivazioni sono diverse, anche se spesso gli emendamenti si assomigliano, ma il risultato non cambia: a chi si è costruito una casa violando tutte le normative esistenti si lancia un segnale esplicito, come aveva facilmente profetizzato l’Istat: un nuovo condono su misura. È semplicemente inaccettabile per un Paese civile, per la tutela dell’ambiente – conclude Ciafani – per gli imprenditori che opera sul mercato dell’edilizia rispettando le regole, ma soprattutto per chi fatica ad avere una casa in cui vivere. Al bisogno di casa si risponda con una legge nazionale per la rigenerazione urbana, senza consumo di suolo, e con risorse adeguate per l’edilizia pubblica”.
SERVE UN PIANO NAZIONALE DI LOTTA ALL’ABUSIVISMO EDILIZIO 
Con l’obiettivo di promuovere un Piano nazionale di lotta all’abusivismo edilizio, Legambiente ha presentato un emendamento alla legge di bilancio, sotto forma di articolo aggiuntivo ( “Misure per il contrasto del fenomeno dell’abusivismo edilizio e per la chiusura delle pratiche inevase di condono edilizio”) che prevede: 50 milioni di euro l’anno per rifinanziare il Fondo per la demolizione di opere abusive del Ministero delle Infrastrutture e dei Trasporti, mettendoli a disposizione oltre che dei Comuni, di prefetture e autorità giudiziaria; 100 milioni di euro per il Fondo di rotazione denominato “Fondo per la demolizione di opere abusive” della Cassa Depositi e Prestiti; 100 milioni di euro l’anno nel capitolo 1360 del bilancio del Ministero della Giustizia destinati all’esecuzione dell’ordine di demolizione e dell’ordine di ripristino dello stato dei luoghi da parte delle Procure e delle Procure generali; l’istituzione presso il Ministero delle infrastrutture di un Fondo in favore dei Comuni per la chiusura delle pratiche di condono edilizio inevase, con una dotazione di 100 milioni di euro l’anno.
 A queste risorse vanno aggiunte nel Piano nazionale l’estensione del potere sostitutivo delle Prefetture (art.10-bis, legge 120/2020) alle ordinanze di demolizione emanate e non eseguite dai Comuni prima dell’approvazione della norma e sanzioni penali adeguate per i dirigenti comunali che omettono di adottare i provvedimenti previsti nei casi di abusivismo edilizio e per i funzionari delle aziende erogatrici di servizi che stipulano contratti, in violazione della normativa vigente, con proprietari di immobili costruiti illegalmente.

items.title: Climate Risk Index 2026: il riscaldamento climatico tra i rischi principali
items.description: 50 morti e centinaia di migliaia di sfollati, migliaia di case distrutte tra Giamaica e altre isole dei Caraibi: questa l’eredità di Melissa, l’uragan
items.body:
Climate Risk Index 2026: il riscaldamento climatico tra i rischi principali

17.11.2025 -                                 Clima, Cambiamenti Climatici, Emissioni gas serra

condividi:

50 morti e centinaia di migliaia di sfollati, migliaia di case distrutte tra Giamaica e altre isole dei Caraibi: questa l’eredità di Melissa, l’uragano che ha raggiunto categoria 5 (la massima possibile), con venti fino a 300 km/h.

Talmaegi e Fung-Wong sono invece gli ultimi due tifoni (nel solo 2025 ce ne sono stati ben 21) che hanno devastato le Filippine nelle scorse settimane, provocando una decina di morti e portando all’evacuazione di 1 milione e 400 mila persone con danni stimati in oltre 4 miliardi di dollari.

Sono numeri davvero impressionanti, che vanno a confermare un trend che pone le Filippine tra i Paesi più colpiti da eventi estremi negli ultimi anni, così come riportato nel “Climate Risk Index 2026” presentato nel corso della COP 30 in corso a Belém che certifica in modo chiaro come uragani, tifoni e altri eventi estremi stiano diventando sempre più frequenti e intensi così come i loro effetti devastanti.

Il Climate Risk Index, pubblicato fin dal 2006, è un report sugli impatti climatici basato su un indice retrospettivo, che classifica i Paesi del Mondo in base ai danni subiti a causa degli eventi meteorologici estremi (numero di vittime e in generale di persone colpite, danni economici).

Si tratta di una pubblicazione curata da Germanwatch, Organizzazione tedesca indipendente che si occupa di sviluppo, ambiente e diritti umani che in oltre 30 anni di attività di advocacy ha realizzato più di 650 progetti in tutto il mondo spesso risultando fondamentali nel contesto delle politiche di azione per il clima.

Il ranking stila una classifica dei Paesi sulla base degli impatti economici e umani subiti, mettendo nelle prime posizioni chi ha subito maggiormente forti piogge (heavy rainfalls), tempeste devastanti (devastating storms), inondazioni mortali (deadly floods)ma anche caldo torrido (Scorching heat) e incendi (raging wildfires) che abbiano avuto effetti devastanti per le comunità, situazione diventata oggi fin troppo comune in alcuni contesti.

Tra il 1995 e il 2024, il periodo coperto dall'analisi dell'indice che di fatto è anche il trentennio in cui si è provato ad attivare una risposta globale alla crisi climatica tramite le COP, gli oltre 9.700 eventi meteorologici estremi che si sono verificati hanno causato più di 832.000 vittime e hanno portato a perdite economiche dirette per quasi 4,5 trilioni di dollari (valori economici non attualizzati).

L’edizione 2026 del Climate Risk Index https://www.germanwatch.org/en/93310 sottolinea il costo crescente dell'inazione in termini economici ma soprattutto di perdite umane ed evidenzia come la frequenza e l’intensità degli eventi e, di conseguenza, i loro effetti devastanti siano in continuo aumento.

Il ranking appena pubblicato mostra come i Paesi più colpiti da eventi estremi nel corso del 2024 siano stati Saint Vincent e Grenadine, Grenada, Chad, Papua Nuova Guinea, Niger e Nepal.

Se la valutazione si allarga all’intero periodo considerato 1995-2024, ai primi posti si ritrovano Repubblica Domenicana, Myanmar, Honduras, Libia e Haiti.

L’Italia in questa classifica è al sedicesimo posto su 174 paesi mappati.

Il grafico mostra i 20 paesi più colpiti in questo periodo in base ai sei indicatori CRI analizzati (quali: * numero assoluto di vittime; * vittime ogni 100.000 abitanti; * numero assoluto di persone colpite; * persone colpite ogni 100.000 abitanti; * perdite economiche assolute; * perdite economiche relative [in percentuale del PIL]).

Gli eventi estremi hanno una intensità ed una frequenza ("tempo di ritorno") sempre più alta nei medesimi territori, che fanno sempre più fatica a riprendersi tra un evento e l’altro: in termini tecnici significa che l'aumento dei fenomeni estremi abbassa la resilienza dei territori.

Un esempio molto vicino a noi è quanto verificatosi in Emilia-Romagna con le due alluvioni della primavera 2023 e dell’autunno 2024.

Per questo motivo la COP30 si conferma essere un appuntamento fondamentale per il futuro delle nostre comunità.

Il contrasto alla crisi climatica deve passare sia attraverso la mitigazione, vale a dire la riduzione tendente all’azzeramento delle emissioni di gas serra, ma è sempre più importante che ad essa si affianchino azioni di adattamento vale a dire una risposta efficace agli effetti che non è possibile evitare.

items.title: Climate Pride, oltre 10 mila persone in piazza
items.description:
Roma ha ospitato la seconda edizione del Climate Pride, la mobilitazione nazionale per il clima promossa da un cartello di oltre 80 associazioni
The p
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie A Roma l’evento che ha unito oltre 80 sigle Roma ha ospitato sabato 15 novembre la seconda edizione del Climate Pride, la mobilitazione nazionale per il clima promossa da un cartello di oltre 80 associazioni e inserita all’interno delle proteste che si stanno svolgendo in tutto il mondo nei giorni in cui è in corso la COP30. In piazza nella Capitale oltre 10 mila persone, tra associazioni, movimenti,cittadine e cittadini, hanno formato una lunga street parade performativa con maschere di organismi, pale eoliche, la scenografia di un antico ulivo palestinese e lo striscione “Dall’Amazzonia all’Europa Giustizia Climatica Planetaria”. È partita da Piazzale Aldo Moro ed è confluita a Largo Preneste, zona est della Capitale, per chiedere ai leader politici riuniti alla COP30 di Belém una svolta concreta nelle politiche climatiche e sociali. Le 82 realtà aderenti hanno portato un messaggio chiaro: in un contesto globale segnato dai crescenti impatti della crisi climatica, da guerre, disuguaglianze e competizione per le risorse, è urgente interrompere la dipendenza dai combustibili fossili e fermare l’escalation del riarmo, pratiche che alimentano nuove forme di colonialismo e aggravano gli squilibri internazionali. La transizione ecologica La transizione ecologica ed energetica rende i paesi più indipendenti dall’importazione di materie prime e risorse energetiche e quindi meno responsabili delle tensioni geopolitiche che spesso sfociano in guerre in tutto il Pianeta. Climate pride Roma La crisi climatica è già oggi una condizione strutturale che colpisce comunità in tutto il mondo e da cui nessun Paese può ritenersi escluso: nonostante il ritiro degli Stati Uniti dagli impegni sul clima negli anni dell’amministrazione Trump e il conseguente rallentamento dell’azione globale, gli eventi estremi continuano ad aumentare, con danni economici cresciuti di dieci volte rispetto al 2000 e arrivati, secondo BloombergNEF, a 1.400 miliardi di dollari nel 2024. L’iniziativa ha voluto anche richiamare l’Unione Europea a sostenere un accordo ambizioso per l’uscita dalle fonti fossili accelerare una transizione ecologica equa, che metta a disposizione risorse anche per i Paesi più esposti agli impatti della crisi climatica. In parallelo, il Climate Pride ha inteso mettere in luce la contraddizione dell’attuale Governo italiano, che da un lato incrementa le spese militari, mentre dall’altro trascura gli investimenti necessari per una giusta transizione ecologica, nonché e il sostegno alle comunità già colpite dai disastri ambientali. Una mobilitazione forte per il clima Il Climate Pride rappresenta solo l’inizio di una mobilitazione che continuerà nei prossimi mesi, anche sui territori, in rete tra tutte le realtà aderenti, a supporto della transizione ecologica e contro le grandi opere fossili inutili, per costruire dal basso percorsi di giustizia climatica, pace e solidarietà. Hanno aderito: A buon diritto, Acli, ActionAid Italia, Agesci (gruppi regionali), Acrobax, ACS – Ulivi Cultura di Pace, AGENDA – Associazione Genitori IC Mastroianni, ANITA Garibaldi APS, Amnesty International Italia, Arci nazionale, Arci servizio civile nazionale, A Sud, Associazione Genitori Giardinieri, Astra, BDS Castelli Romani – Roma Sud, BDS Roma, Brancaleone, Bologna for Climate Justice, Casale Garibaldi – common at work, Casetta Rossa, CGIL, Ci sarà un bel clima, CLAP – Camere del Lavoro Autonomo e Precario, Clean Cities, Climate Art Project, Climate Reality Italia, Comitato Pratone di Torre Spaccata, Collettivo No Porto, Coordinamento Sì Parco Sì Ospedale No Stadio, Coordinamento CERS Roma e Lazio, Communia, COSPE, CSOA La Strada, CSOA Ex Snia, CSOA Insurgencia, Ecorà, Esc Atelier Autogestito, Esn Italia, Extinction Rebellion Italia, Forum del Terzo Settore, Forum Disuguaglianze Diversità, Forum Territoriale Permanente Parco delle Energie, Fridays For Future Italia, Giustizia per Taranto, Greenpeace Italia, GKN, Lab Puzzle Bene Comune, Legambiente, Libera Contro le Mafie, Link Coordinamento Universitario, Lunaria, Marevivo, Movimento Giovani Save The Children, Movimento per la Decrescita Felice, Nonna Roma, Nero edizioni, Per il Clima, fuori dal Fossile, Oxfam, Rete degli Studenti Medi, Rete della Conoscenza, Rete Ecosocialista, Rete Pace e Disarmo, Rete Emergenza Climatica e Ambientale, Rete nazionale A Pieno Regime, Rinascimento Green, Salvaiciclisti Roma, Santa Libbirata La Carretteria, Save the children, Scomodo, Streets For Kids, Studenti alla Terza, SemiVolanti, SpinTime Lab, Stalker Lab, Villetta social Lab, Vivinstrada, UDS – Unione degli Studenti, UDU – Unione degli Universitari, UISP, Ultima Generazione, Un Ponte Per, VAS, WWF Italia, Yalla Roma

items.description: Oggi a Roma la Mobilitazione nazionale sul clima per chiedere alla COP30 una svolta concreta nelle politiche climatiche e sociali: un Pianeta per tut
items.body:
15 Novembre 2025

Clima

Cittadinanza Attiva

Climate pride, 10 mila persone in piazza

15 Novembre 2025

Legambiente

15 Novembre 2025

Clima

Cittadinanza Attiva

Oggi a Roma la Mobilitazione nazionale sul clima per chiedere alla COP30 una svolta concreta nelle politiche climatiche e sociali: un Pianeta per tutti, non solo per pochi.  
Roma ha ospitato oggi pomeriggio la seconda edizione del Climate Pride, la mobilitazione nazionale per il clima promossa da un cartello di oltre 80 associazioni e inserita all’interno delle proteste che si stanno svolgendo in tutto il mondo nei giorni in cui è in corso la COP30 in Amazzonia.

10 mila in piazza con un messaggio chiaro
In piazza nella Capitale oltre 10 mila persone, tra associazioni, movimenti, cittadine e cittadini, hanno formato una lunga street parade performativa con maschere di organismi, pale eoliche, la scenografia di un antico ulivo palestinese e lo striscione “Dall’Amazzonia all’Europa Giustizia Climatica Planetaria”. È partita da Piazzale Aldo Moro ed è confluita a Largo Preneste, zona est della Capitale, per chiedere ai leader politici riuniti alla COP30 di Belém una svolta concreta nelle politiche climatiche e sociali.
Le 82 realtà aderenti hanno portato un messaggio chiaro: in un contesto globale segnato dai crescenti impatti della crisi climatica,  da guerre, disuguaglianze e competizione per le risorse, è urgente interrompere la dipendenza dai combustibili fossili e fermare l’escalation del riarmo, pratiche che alimentano nuove forme di colonialismo e aggravano gli squilibri internazionali

La crisi climatica è già oggi una condizione strutturale che colpisce comunità in tutto il mondo e da cui nessun Paese può ritenersi escluso: nonostante il ritiro degli Stati Uniti dagli impegni sul clima negli anni dell’amministrazione Trump e il conseguente rallentamento dell’azione globale, gli eventi estremi continuano ad aumentare, con danni economici cresciuti di dieci volte rispetto al 2000 e arrivati, secondo BloombergNEF, a 1.400 miliardi di dollari nel 2024.

In parallelo, il Climate Pride ha inteso mettere in luce la contraddizione dell’attuale Governo italiano, che da un lato incrementa le spese militari, mentre dall’altro trascura gli investimenti necessari per una giusta transizione ecologica, nonché e il sostegno alle comunità già colpite dai disastri ambientali.
Il Climate Pride rappresenta solo l’inizio di una mobilitazione che continuerà nei prossimi mesi, anche sui territori, in rete tra tutte le realtà aderenti, a supporto della transizione ecologica e contro le grandi opere fossili inutili, per costruire dal basso percorsi di giustizia climatica, pace e solidarietà.
